Hello my name is Jonathan Worth and as
well as being freelance photographer I'm

also a researcher at Newcastle
University's Open Lab in the UK.

The interviews you're about to hear are part
of a series that, along with the web platform

and connected classes, seek to
create a space for
critical engagement with visual storytelling.
The relationship between the photographer, the subject and the audience
(the three stakeholders in every photograph)

are central to the Talking Pictures
interviews, but there are occasions when

those stakeholders might not be three
different people.
In the case of the self-portrait, the photographer and the subject to the same person.

In the case of the selfie that isn't shared or
published, the photographer, the subject
and the audience are one and the same.
The theme for this session is "Interpretation" and the people who have
agreed to help us think about that are
the Scottish photographer Graham Macindoe and the U.S. journalist Susan Stellan.

For reasons that will become
clear

Graham chose not to share his
self-portraits for over ten years

and many of the images from this series
and from this time in his life,
he's still not chosen to publish.
Both him and Susan reflect on the ethical implications
of representing other people, the duty of care for the vulnerable

and they consider how the
effect and impact of an image might be

felt long after it was made, and long
after the subject
may have moved on with their life.
I first met Graham in New York in 1998 he helped me
find a place to live and help me find places to work.
He was intense. He was brash with his

thick Scottish accent that he refused to
let go of, and he was funny.

He was generous, he was very caring of his
friends, and he was successful as well.
He was shooting huge jobs. He was travelling all over the world.

He someone who was constantly in motion,
both figuratively and literally.
He was also a compulsive collector both of the ephemeral and of images.
Everything had a story attached to it and everything was super tasteful.
To this day the photographs of that period of my life, that hang in my home, were made by Graham.

We moved away from New York at the end
of 2001 and towards the end it had

become harder and harder to keep up with
him.
By 2005 it was impossible and it remains a regret that we lost touch.
Back in the UK news of Graham now was

coming second and third-hand. I learned
that he he'd got divorced.
I'd learned that he wasn't working anymore.
I learned that there'd been a newspaper report of an explosion at his house,
that he'd been arrested, and that finally he was in prison.
As you listen to this interview you'll hear from Graham the photographer,

Graham the subject and
Graham the publisher.
You'll hear how even at his lowest ebb he was still considering the ethical implications of

making other people's images, and how he
and Susan chose to share the work,

taking into consideration how the contexts
would affect how the various audiences
would interpret it and be affected.
And so it's fitting that Susan has the last word,

not only on this story, but also on
this interview itself.
There are also links to related bodies of work that, along with this material, should inform

a critical discourse about vulnerability,
responsibility and how we choose to
represent issues and so frame the conversations around them.

living room, and you might hear a few

sure what I was going to do in photography.
I knew I wanted to work within the field of photography, I fallen in love with it
and was pretty passionate about it,

annual reports and photographing

paid what you're getting paid for

story about them, that are not on that

more inclined to reveal things about themselves.
Even if you don't agree with it. I've photographed some people that

politically, I might not agree with, or you

Wow! But they  always have something interesting about them that reveals something to me about how other people live their lives.
Those jobs are more fulfilling for me.
I enjoyed that sort of,  you know,  meeting these people who are not in the public eye

and saw some magazines doing a feature on it.
I started working as a photographer because

I was someone who was always
taking pictures. I took portraits of friends,
I photographed landscapes, I did.. I photographed everything that was going on around me you know,

.. sometimes I think it's are almost like an affliction.

I tell them and I send them on the first day

So I've had several years of working as a really successful commercial photographer,

advertising agencies, flying all around the world.

Being lucky enough to meet
celebrities and you know, sort of the dream

world of a photographer to be perfectly
honest with you.
But er.. . during that period

dabbling with drugs and..
it just took me off at a tangent that I never, ever really expected in my life you know.

I slowly but surely and very insidiously,
the drugs kicked in and I became a very,
very bad heroin and crack cocaine addict.

and the notebooks and the
Polaroids and the undeveloped rolls of

hundreds and hundreds of pictures I had taken during those years over maybe

you'll say and do a lot of things as an addict ..
and say everything's okay then

the reality of day when you're clean you
just go "My God I would never do or say that"

so I've decided to make it all

[Susan] Another point in the code of ethics is "Give special consideration to
vulnerable subjects"
and that's something that Graham has addressed in explaining why he decided not to photograph other addicts

is this issue of consent.
You know, we recognise now that someone

who is addicted to drugs and has a
serious problem, you know,
they have difficulties with decision-making and making rational choices. So, to say that

this person can consent to having their
picture taken and then published I think

is a bit problematic because, you know, we
recognise that you know,

they aren't really making decisions that are
informed by rational choices
and I think that is something that we really need to think about because
that person might get clean and then later regret that their images out in the world

showing them at their worst moment and
they can't take it back.
[Graham] I had started taking photographs of the people around me in their environment
and sometimes I've ended up in the pictures and then
it just felt more pertinent for me to photograph myself because I was living that life and
I shouldn't really be pointing the camera at other people I felt I should be pointed it at myself.

[Susan] So fast forward a few years and I had
lost touch with him at that point
he had really gone downhill.
We kept in touch occasionally via email but then,
he just disappeared off the radar, and I started reaching out to a couple other people who had known him.
Just sort of under the assumption that maybe he'd overdosed
because his phone had been turned off. The website he used to promote his photography was offline.
[Graham] I mean I spent close to a decade of my life juggling too much drinking dabbling with drugs
turning, into a serious addiction,  and
everything that went along with that.
And I kept telling myself that I could get clean on my own.
I kept thinking it was something I could do. Just to willpower and strength,

and it's just like, I just need
to buckle down and do it, but you know,
I was totally incapable.
Strangely enough the most devastating thing for me at that time

and I think it's one of the biggest penal colonies in the world,

which totally blew me away
because
it was somewhere I never, ever thought I would end up in.
So I "cold-turkeyed" in a cell in Rikers Island, which was a really, really painful thing you know?
The physicality of it.
And then once you get that out of your system a little bit, the readjusting in your body to being clean

and then psychologically the..
you know, realisation of where the last

several years of your life have been, are
really crushing you know?
I mean it was a really, really tough time for me but I also gave me that moment of clarity,
as they call it,  where I sort of could look back and say "Wow!", I just put myself through this

and my friends through this, and my family
through this, and thinking of the collateral

damage to my Mom and my Dad and my
friends and my son and everyone was really big.

[Susan] By the time I tracked him
down he was actually due to be released from Rikers and
rather than getting released, he ended up in Homeland Security custody
and was very quickly moved to detention centres in, first in downtown Manhattan,
and then in New Jersey, and then Pennsylvania.

So I managed to get someone at the prison
where he was being held in Pennsylvania

to give him my phone number and that's
when we reconnected.
[Graham] I was in a County Jail in Pennsylvania that had an immigration wing and I found out they had a

24/7 cognitive behavioural therapy
program in there for four months

and that's, that's how I got clean
essentially, was in a prison rehabilitation program.
And it set the groundwork for me to, when I got out,  to build on that
and I've been clean ever since which is seven and half years, or something like that.

[Susan] We talked on the phone, we exchanged these
really intense letters, and you know by

the time his final hearing was coming up,
it was as lawyer who actually asked if I

would be okay with Graham coming to stay
with me for a while if he got released?

So all of a sudden he was on a bus

That was the first time I seen him in almost two years so, he came to stay with me and

him [laughs] we actually just got married in May of 2017
But when he was released, maybe not nine months clean but also

having spent nine months incarcerated, so
he wasn't Graham the photographer.
I think he didn't know who he was and that was the process of rebuilding, you know not

just from that time away from everything,
but also almost a decade of addiction.

So, it was a long process, I mean he, at first
he didn't have any interest in picking up a camera
he would go to a grocery store and just stand in the aisles kind of mystified by

You know, he didn't have any interest in having a phone.
He didn't have any interest in a computer. You know, it took a long time for Graham to

I feel pleasure from. You know, whether it's a great meal, or sex, or running, or

photography, you know, and that's because
your brain changes from addiction you

know, particularly with dopamine's and
you know,
I don't think people get prepared for how long that's going to take.

ephemera and stuff,
